content.text:
# BAFTA Award for Best Actress in a Leading Role__disambig_1

Best Actress in a Leading Role is a British Academy Film Award presented annually by the British Academy of Film and Television Arts (BAFTA) to recognize an actress who has delivered an outstanding leading performance in a film.
* From 1952 to 1967, there were two Best Actress awards presented, Best British Actress and Best Foreign Actress.
* From 1968 onwards, the two awards merged into one award, which from 1968 to 1984 was known as Best Actress.
* From 1985 to present, the award has been known by its current name of Best Actress in a Leading Role.
In the following lists, the titles and names in bold with a gold background are the winners and recipients respectively; those not in bold are the nominees. The years given are those in which the films under consideration were released, not the year of the ceremony, which always takes place the following year.
Winners and nominees
was the inaugural winner, for A Streetcar Named Desire (1952).]]
won thrice, for Golden Helmet (1952), The Witches of Salem (1957), and Room at the Top (1958).]]
won thrice, for Roman Holiday (1953), ''The Nun's Story (1959), and Charade (1963).]]
won twice, for Ask Any Girl (1959) and The Apartment (1960).]]
won for Two Women (1961)]]
won twice, for Lili (1953) and The L-Shaped Room (1962).]]
won twice, for Hud (1963) and In Harms Way (1965)]]
won thrice, for The Miracle Worker (1962), The Pumpkin Eater (1964), and 84 Charing Cross Road (1987).]]
won for Darling (1965).]]
won for Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf? (1966).]]
won for Viva Maria! (1966)]]
won for A Man and a Woman (1967)]]
won twice, for Guess Who's Coming to Dinner / The Lion in Winter (1968) and On Golden Pond (1981).]]
won four times in 1969, 1984, 1985, and 1987.]]
won for Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid / Tell Them Willie Boy Is Here (1970).]]
won for Sunday Bloody Sunday (1971).]]
won for Cabaret (1972).]]
won for Summer Wishes, Winter Dreams (1973).]]
won for Alice Doesn't Live Here Anymore (1974).]]
won for Annie Hall (1977).]]
won twice, for Julia (1977) and The China Syndrome (1978).]]
twice for The French Lieutenant's Woman (1981) and The Iron Lady (2011).]]
won for My Brilliant Career (1980)]]
won for Educating Rita (1983).]]
won for Shirley Valentine (1989)]]
won for The Silence of the Lambs (1991).]]
won twice, for Howards End (1992) and Sense and Sensibility (1995).]]
won for The Piano (1993).]]
won for The Client (1994).]]
won for Secrets & Lies (1996).]]
won twice, for Mrs Brown (1997) and Iris (2001).|alt=Photo of Judi Dench at the 2007 British Academy Film Awards]]
won thrice, for Elizabeth (1998), Blue Jasmine (2013), and Tár (2022).|alt=Photo of Cate Blanchett at the 2015 Cannes Film Festival]]
won for American Beauty (1999).|alt=Photo of Annette Bening at the 2013 Tribeca International Film Festival]]
won for Erin Brockovich (2000).|alt=Photo of Julia Roberts at the 2016 Cannes Film Festival]]
won for The Hours (2002).|alt=Photo of Nicole Kidman at the 2017 Cannes Film Festival]]
won for Lost in Translation (2003).|alt=Photo of Scarlett Johansson at the 2019 San Diego Comic-Con]]
won for Vera Drake (2004)]]
won for Walk the Line (2005).|alt=Photo of Reese Witherspoon at the 2014 Toronto International Film Festival]]
won for The Queen (2006).|alt=Photo of Helen Mirren at the 2014 British Independent Film Awards]]
won for La Vie en Rose (2007).|alt=Photo of Marion Cotillard at the 2017 Cabourg Film Festival]]
won for The Reader (2008).|alt=Photo of Kate Winslet at the 2011 Venice Film Festival]]
won for An Education (2009).|alt=Photo of Carey Mulligan in Sydney, Australia at the premiere of "The Great Gatsby" in 2013]]
won for Black Swan (2010).|alt=Photo of Natalie Portman at the 2015 Cannes Film Festival]]
won at age 85 for Amour (2012)|alt=Photo of Emmanuelle Riva at the 2012 Cannes Film Festival]]
won for Still Alice (2014).|alt=Photo of Julianne Moore at the 2014 Tribeca International Film Festival]]
won for Room (2015).|alt=Photo of Brie Larson at the 2016 San Diego Comic-Con]]
won twice, for La La Land (2016) and Poor Things (2023).|alt=Photo of Julianne Moore at the 2014 Toronto International Film Festival.]]
won twice, for Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri (2017) and Nomadland (2020).|alt=Photo of Frances McDormand at the 2015 Screen Actors Guild Awards]]
won for The Favourite (2018).|alt=Photo of Olivia Colman at the 2014 British Independent Film Awards]]
won for Judy (2019).]]
won for After Love (2021).]]
won for Anora (2024)]]

Notes
: A: Rules from the 1960s to the 1970s allowed for a performer to receive a single citation which could honor their work in more than one film. Shirley MacLaine, Julie Andrews, Julie Christie, Bibi Andersson, Katharine Hepburn, Barbra Streisand, Katharine Ross, Goldie Hawn, and Stéphane Audran were all nominated for their roles in two different films in the same category, while Mia Farrow was nominated for three films.
: B: Elliot Page was nominated before his gender transition in 2020.
: C: Emmanuelle Riva and Marion Cotillard both received nominations for French-speaking roles. It was the first time that multiple foreign-language performances were nominated for Best Actress in the same year since separate Best Foreign Actress and Best British Actress awards were folded into a single category in 1968.
